sideA: Al hacer checkout, la Cotización (ASO) se convierte en una Orden de Venta real en el módulo de Order Management.

sideB.text: Upon checkout, the Quote (ASO) is converted into an actual Sales Order in the Order Management (OM) module.
The checkout process triggers the conversion of the ASO Quote into a confirmed Sales Order in OM.
Data moves from the ASO module to the Order Management (OM) module when the Quote becomes a Booked Order.
When checking out, the Quote becomes an actual Sales Order.
Upon completing checkout, the Quote turns into a Sales Order.
The Quote becomes a Sales Order at checkout.
Checkout turns the Quote into a Sales Order.
After checkout, the Quote converts to a Sales Order.

note:
[Upon checkout] is a formal way to say 'when doing checkout'.

[Triggers the conversion] describes the automatic process started by the user's action.

~Doing checkout...~ (Unnatural grammar: Use 'When checking out' or 'Upon checkout'.)

sideA: Veo que el campo aún no se actualiza.

sideB.text: I see that the field is not updating yet.
I notice the field hasn't updated yet.
It seems the field isn't updating.
I see that the field is not updated yet.

note:
[Field] refers to the UI input or Database column.

Use [Not updating] (Continuous) to describe the current state.

~I style see that the field is not updated~ (Typo/Grammar: 'Style' is incorrect here. Likely meant 'still', but the phrasing 'is not updated' implies a static state rather than a pending process.)

sideA: Ahora chequeé de nuevo, y ahora sí veo la última versión.

sideB.text: I checked again, and now I do see the latest version.
I just checked again, and I can see the latest version now.
After checking again, the latest version is visible.
I checked it again, and now I see the latest version.

note:
Using [I do see] adds emphasis (affirmative), meaning 'Yes, really, I see it now'.

~...now I see the last version~ (Imprecise: Use 'latest version' for the most recent update. 'Last' implies the final one ever.)

~...now I do see the last version~ (Rejected: 'Last' implies finality. In software, always use 'latest' for the newest version.)

sideA: Le pedimos ayuda al empleado de soporte.

sideB.text: We asked the support employee for help.
We requested assistance from the support staff.
We reached out to the support employee for help.

note:
Structure: [Ask someone FOR help].

[Reach out to] is a professional way to say 'contactar' or 'pedir ayuda'.

~We asked for help to the support employee~ (Grammar: Incorrect structure. Correct forms: 'Ask [someone] for help' or 'Ask for help FROM [someone]'. Never 'ask for help to'.)

sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será por chat o llamadas por Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be via chat or Teams calls.
We'll communicate mainly through Teams chat or calls.
Our primary contact methods will be Teams chat and calls.
We will mainly use Microsoft Teams for communication.
Our main tool of communication will be Microsoft Teams.

note:
[Via] is a useful preposition meaning 'by way of' (e.g., via chat, via email).

[Through] is also commonly used (e.g., through Teams).

~Our main tool... will be by Microsoft team~ (Correction: 1. The app is called 'Teams' (plural). 2. Don't say 'the tool will be by'. Say: 'Our main tool is Teams' or 'We use Teams'.)

~...tool... will be on/by Microsoft Teams~ (Grammar: A tool is not 'by' the software. We communicate 'on' or 'via' Teams, but the tool *is* Teams.)

sideA: ¿Puedes darme exactamente los pasos que hiciste para llegar ahí?

sideB.text: Can you give me the exact steps you took to get there?
Could you provide the specific steps you followed to reach that point?
Can you tell me the exact steps you took to arrive at that state?
Can you give me the exact steps to get there?

note:
[Steps you took] is the colocation for 'pasos que hiciste'. ~Steps you made~ is unnatural.

[To get there] refers to arriving at the error state.

~...steps that you did...~ (Collocation: We 'take' or 'follow' steps, we do not 'do' them.)

sideA: Mi inglés sigue mejorando, y en reuniones grandes tiendo a quedarme callado.

sideB.text: My English is still improving, and in big meetings I tend to stay quiet.
I'm still working on my English, so I tend to be quieter in large meetings.
My English is a work in progress, and I tend to listen more than speak in big groups.
My English keeps improving, and in big meetings I tend to stay quiet.

note:
[Tend to] describes a habit or inclination.

[Work in progress] is a positive way to say something is not yet perfect but is improving.

sideA: Debo contener al cliente en Japón y Corea.

sideB.text: I must manage the client in Japan and Korea.
I need to keep the client in Japan and Korea contained.
My role involves managing expectations for clients in Japan and Korea.
I need to contain the client in Japan and Korea.

note:
To [contain] a client in an IT context often means to manage their anxiety or keep a situation under control. [Manage expectations] is also a very professional alternative.

~I must to contain~ is incorrect. Modal verbs like [must] are followed directly by the verb.

~...client from Japan...~ (Preposition: 'En Japón' translates to 'in Japan' (location). 'From Japan' implies origin.)
